ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a base understanding of the evolution of French literature from the 12th century to the 20th century. I also sharpened my reading skills and became more comfortable writing in French. Lastly, I found the class discussions, final presentation, and final oral exam to be really helpful in allowing me to build/present my own argument.
Reading and understanding French literature from several periods in time
Breadth of knowledge on French literature and gained better speaking proficiency.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strengths of this class include the distribution of assignments, the interesting class discussions, and the diversity of content presented. The only improvement I would suggest would be to allocate more time to discuss/read longer novels.
Good seminar, and balance of lecture vs conversation

I think the course had a good selection of literature spanning centuries-old literature to works by current authors, which provided a framework for us to discuss different eras of French literary history (and history in general) as we read. The inclusion of oral presentations by students on topics of our choice was a nice way to allow us to explore an area of literature/history we were particularly interested in. One change I think might help students get more out of readings would be lecturing about the history of the author/the time period of the readings during the class before we discuss the reading rather than on the day that the reading has been assigned for, because then we would be able to read already knowing the historical context or having some information about the author and their writing that helps us understand what we read more fully and be better-prepared for robust discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Especially if you enjoy discussions about French literature and want to delve into the work of authors that you may have heard of before but haven't read.
Yes, great way to get introduced to a large variety of French literature and develop the background to appreciate it.

Yes, I would recommend this course. I had none to little experience reading French literature and took this course after FREN 160, and it felt like an appropriate level. Some of the readings are time-consuming (at least if you are not completely fluent), but I found that even reading the material that was more difficult to understand was a good way to expand my vocabulary even though it did make some of the readings take a long time.

extras.title: FREN 170 01 - Intro Study of French Lit
